thread.title: Doctors DON'T support clinical use of medicinal marijuana | Daily Mail Online
thread.title_full: Doctors DON'T support clinical use of medicinal marijuana | Daily Mail Online

author: Freya Noble
title: Doctors DON'T support clinical use of medicinal marijuana | Daily Mail Online
text: Share this article Share 'It is a long way from being a panacea for the whole range of conditions it's claimed to be useful for, but in those circumstances where a doctor makes a judgment that it should be prescribed, it's entirely appropriate that patients or their families can access a legal supply, rather than resorting to the black market,' Dr Gannon said. On Wednesday it was announced that the sale of medicinal cannabis had been approved by the federal government, and it's expected Australia will have a store of the imported drug in eight weeks. The medication is currently sourced from overseas on a case-by-case basis, and the system for sourcing it often involves delays, reported the ABC . The medication is currently sourced from overseas on a case-by-case basis, and the system for sourcing it often involves delays (stock image) Currently, the medication is sourced from overseas on a case-by-case basis, a system involving delays. Health Minister Greg Hunt on Wednesday announced that approved importers will be able to buy the medication from overseas and store it in Australia for immediate distribution until domestic production meets local needs. The move will make it easier for patients who now must wait for the product to be imported once prescribed an authorised doctor. 'What this means is that there will be a supply to meet all Australian demand,' Mr Hunt told ABC Radio. Local production was only legalised late last year and will take time to develop, he said. The move will make it easier for patients who now must wait for the product to be imported once prescribed an authorised doctor (stock image) The first licence for private cultivation was only issued last week. 'We want to get on right now in making easier and faster access available for patients who are ultimately the real users of safe, high quality, appropriately-obtained medicine,' Mr Hunt said. Victoria expects locally-sourced medicinal cannabis to be available by the middle of the year or a little bit later. The drug is used to treat patients with chronic or painful illnesses including cancer, severe epilepsy and motor neurone disease. Health minister Greg Hunt (pictured) said: 'We want to get on right now in making easier and faster access available for patients who are ultimately the real users of safe, high quality, appropriately-obtained medicine Read more: Share or comment on this article 8
